canonical_title: Paris Jackson Reveals She Has a Perforated Septum: ‘Don’t Do Drugs Kids’

members.title: Paris Jackson Reveals She Has a Perforated Septum: ‘Don’t Do Drugs Kids’
key_points: Paris Jackson revealed she has a perforated septum, a condition caused by drug use, which she attributes to past addiction.
She emphasized in a TikTok-reposted video that drug use 'ruined her life' and urged others, especially youth, not to experiment with drugs.
The perforated septum has been present since age 20 and is currently causing physical challenges in music recording, though she has chosen not to undergo surgery due to drug-related risks.

canonical_title: MLB Announces New Gambling Safeguards After Guardians Pitchers Indicted in Betting Scandal

members.title: MLB Announces New Gambling Safeguards After Guardians Pitchers Indicted in Betting Scandal
key_points: MLB has implemented new gambling safeguards, capping pitch-level bets at $200 and banning parlaying of pitch outcomes to reduce the risk of insider manipulation.
Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz, two Cleveland Guardians pitchers, were indicted on charges including wire fraud, conspiracy to influence games, and money laundering related to rigged pitch bets.
The indictment alleges that the players coordinated with corrupt bettors to provide inside information on pitch types, speeds, and outcomes, enabling fraudulent bets worth at least $460,000.

canonical_title: At least 12 killed in Islamabad suicide attack – the most deadly assault in the Pakistani capital since 2008

members.title: At least 12 killed in Islamabad suicide attack – the most deadly assault in the Pakistani capital since 2008
key_points: A suicide bombing in Islamabad killed 12 people and injured over 20, marking the deadliest such attack in the city in nearly 20 years.
Jamaat-ul-Ahrar (JuA), a faction of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), claimed responsibility for the attack, while the TTP distanced itself from it.

The attack took place in the parking lot of the High Court in Islamabad, where security checks are normally enforced; the suspect was reportedly observed loitering and failed to enter the complex before attacking a police vehicle.

digest_abridged:
A suicide bombing in Islamabad killed 12 and injured 20, the deadliest such attack in the city since 2008.

canonical_title: Bihar election: Can Modi buck Gen Z rage in India’s youngest state?

members.title: Bihar election: Can Modi buck Gen Z rage in India’s youngest state?
key_points: Bihar, India’s youngest and poorest state, is witnessing a surge in youth-led political activism driven by frustration over educational deficiencies, unemployment, caste-based marginalization, and institutional corruption.
The Bihar election serves as a critical test for Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ability to retain support from India’s largest youth demographic, despite growing Gen Z anger across South Asia.

Youth dissatisfaction is fueled by systemic issues: poor educational infrastructure, lack of employment opportunities, delayed or non-existent government promises (e.g., cash transfers), and anti-migrant violence.

members.title: So long, peak oil: World demand could now grow until 2050, a top agency says

The IEA's 'current policies scenario' projects oil demand reaching 113 million barrels per day by mid-century, an increase of about 13% from 2024 levels.
The scenario is based on existing government policies, not climate goals, and reflects divergent energy choices made by nations.

canonical_title: US Supreme Court extends order allowing Trump to withhold food aid

members.title: US Supreme Court extends order allowing Trump to withhold food aid
key_points: The US Supreme Court extended a previous order allowing President Donald Trump to withhold food assistance under the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), marking a significant escalation of legal conflict during a government shutdown.

This decision comes amid the longest government shutdown in US history, which disrupted food benefits for millions, left federal workers unpaid, and caused air traffic cancellations due to staffing shortages.
The suspension of SNAP benefits from November 1, 2025, was the first time in 60 years that such benefits were fully halted, raising concerns about food insecurity and public welfare.

canonical_title: Marion County Agrees to Pay Over $3 Million After Police Raid on Local Newspaper Sparks National Debate Over Press Freedom

members.title: Marion County Agrees to Pay Over $3 Million After Police Raid on Local Newspaper Sparks National Debate Over Press Freedom
key_points: A rural Kansas county agreed to pay over $3 million and issue an apology after a police raid on a local weekly newspaper, the Marion County Record, in August 2023.

The raid, involving both county sheriff’s officers and city police, targeted the newspaper’s offices, editor Eric Meyer’s home, and the home of former city council member Ruth Herbel, raising national concerns about press freedom and civil liberties.

The search warrants were based on a disputed claim that the newspaper illegally obtained a restaurant owner’s driving record, but two special prosecutors later found no evidence of wrongdoing, calling the warrants legally unjustified.

Marion County agreed to pay over $3 million and apologize after a 2023 raid on the Marion County Record newspaper, sparking national debate over press freedom.

canonical_title: Dozens of Venezuelans deported from US to notorious Salvadoran prison subjected to torture, rights groups claim in new report
entities: United States Department of Homeland Security (DHS)

members.title: Dozens of Venezuelans deported from US to notorious Salvadoran prison subjected to torture, rights groups claim in new report
key_points: Dozens of Venezuelans were deported from the United States to El Salvador’s Terrorism Confinement Center (Cecot), where they allegedly faced torture, sexual violence, solitary confinement, and psychological abuse.
The report by Human Rights Watch and Cristosal claims systemic human rights violations at Cecot, including beatings, humiliation, denial of legal access, and suicide attempts.

The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) defended the deportation, asserting that the deportees were members of violent gangs like Tren de Aragua and MS-13, though evidence shows only 3% of the group had violent U.S. convictions, and half had no criminal records.

members.title: Turkish Military Cargo Plane Crashes in Georgia Near Azerbaijan Border
key_points: A Turkish military C-130 cargo plane crashed in Georgia near the border with Azerbaijan on November 11, 2025, with 20 people on board, including crew.
No immediate confirmation of casualties was given, but President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, along with leaders from Georgia and Azerbaijan, stated that some were believed to have been killed.
The plane lost contact with air traffic control shortly after entering Georgian airspace and did not issue a distress call, according to the Georgian aviation authority.

The Justice Department, under Ed Martin, is pushing for Peters' transfer to a federal prison, despite the fact that state convictions cannot be pardoned by the federal government.

canonical_title: Collapse of Sonder, a Marriott-backed hotel chain, leaves guests stranded mid-stay

members.title: Collapse of Sonder, a Marriott-backed hotel chain, leaves guests stranded mid-stay
key_points: Sonder, a Marriott-backed short-term rental company, collapsed due to financial difficulties and the termination of its licensing agreement with Marriott.
The sudden end of the partnership left thousands of guests stranded mid-stay, with some given only 10–15 minutes to vacate their rooms.
Marriott cited Sonder’s financial default as the reason for ending the 20-year licensing agreement, though guests and media have blamed Marriott for the fallout.

canonical_title: With an upcoming vote in the House, an end to the shutdown is in sight

members.title: With an upcoming vote in the House, an end to the shutdown is in sight
key_points: The U.S. Senate voted 60 to 40 to pass a continuing resolution that would fund much of the government through January 30, 2026, and provide funding for some agencies through the end of September 2026.
The shutdown will not end immediately; the U.S. House of Representatives must also pass the legislation before President Trump can sign it into law.

The funding package includes provisions to reverse Trump-era reductions in federal workforce, protect against further layoffs through January 30, provide backpay for federal employees, and fully fund SNAP through September 30, 2026.

The scandal implicates several close associates of President Volodymyr Zelensky, including former Deputy Prime Minister Oleksiy Chernyshov and businessman Timur Mindich, who is a co-owner of Zelensky’s former TV studio Kvartal95 and has reportedly fled the country.

Anti-corruption bodies Nabu and Sap revealed that contractors were being paid kickbacks of 10% to 15% of contract values, with the funds laundered through Kyiv-based offices linked to the family of Andriy Derkach, and some money transferred to Russia.

key_points: Bees can process the duration of light flashes and use this temporal information to decide where to forage, a first in insect cognition.
This ability demonstrates that bees are not simple reflex machines but complex animals with flexible learning and memory.
The study shows bees can differentiate between novel stimuli (flash durations) they have never seen before, suggesting advanced cognitive flexibility.

members.title: Scientists now know that bees can process time, a first in insects

Bees distinguish between short and long flashes based solely on duration, not on food smell or visual cues.

key_points: Gregory Bovino, the top Border Patrol official, is planning to leave Chicago as early as this week, moving to cities like Charlotte, North Carolina, and New Orleans, in line with President Donald Trump’s broader immigration enforcement strategy.

The decision follows a direct rebuke from US District Court Judge Sara Ellis, who ruled that Bovino lied about the use of force during a protest, specifically denying a tackle on protester Scott Blackburn, which the judge found to be a clear violation of due process.
Judge Ellis issued a preliminary injunction requiring federal agents to warn protesters twice before deploying tear gas or pepper balls, which the Trump administration is appealing to overturn.

key_points: Rev. Jesse Jackson, 84, a prominent civil rights leader and protégé of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has been hospitalized for progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), a rare neurodegenerative disorder affecting movement, balance, and eye control.
Jackson has lived with Parkinson’s disease since at least 2017, and in April 2024, his PSP diagnosis was confirmed, marking a progression in his long-term health journey.
PSP is a rare neurological condition that typically affects individuals in their 60s and leads to severe disability within three to five years, with symptoms initially resembling Parkinson’s disease.

canonical_title: Want Fewer Morning Aches? You Might Need to Change the Way You Sleep

members.title: Want Fewer Morning Aches? You Might Need to Change the Way You Sleep
key_points: Improper sleep posture can lead to morning muscle aches, especially in the neck, shoulders, and lower back.
Sleeping in a position that matches your standing posture — with a straight line from head to tailbone — helps maintain spinal alignment and reduces muscle strain.

Using the right pillow (based on sleep position) supports neck and spine alignment; back sleepers should use medium-firm, ergonomic pillows; side sleepers need loft to support the neck without elevating the head.

members.title: Pressure grows for release of penguins 'trapped' at London aquarium
key_points: Dozens of British lawmakers have called for the release of 15 Gentoo penguins housed in a basement at the Sea Life London Aquarium, claiming their living conditions are 'utterly unacceptable'.
The penguins are denied access to daylight, fresh air, and adequate space for natural behaviors, with only 6–7 feet of depth for diving, far below their wild diving capacity of up to 600 feet.
Over 37,000 people have signed a petition calling for the penguins’ relocation to a more suitable environment.

The penguins are housed in a small enclosure measuring only 6–7 feet deep, far below the 600 feet they can dive in the wild, raising concerns about their physical and behavioral well-being.
Animal welfare advocates argue that the enclosure fails to meet the penguins’ natural needs, and that one individual, Polly, has been held underground for over 14 years.

canonical_title: Controversial death penalty and foreign media bills clear first reading in Israel’s parliament

members.title: Controversial death penalty and foreign media bills clear first reading in Israel’s parliament
key_points: Israel’s parliament passed the death penalty bill in its first reading with 39 votes to 16, advancing it to committee review.
The bill, championed by National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir, would expand the death penalty for terrorism and nationalist murder, with no room for extenuating circumstances.
The military courts in the occupied West Bank would gain the power to impose the death penalty by simple majority, removing the previous requirement of unanimous consent.

canonical_title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration’s claims linking Tylenol and autism

members.title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration’s claims linking Tylenol and autism
key_points: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., despite lacking a medical background, has repeatedly promoted unfounded claims linking Tylenol use during pregnancy to autism, contributing to public health misinformation.

The World Health Organization and other reputable health agencies have consistently stated there is no consistent scientific link between Tylenol and autism, emphasizing the importance of medical consultation over self-medication.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton filed a lawsuit against Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, alleging deceptive marketing of Tylenol as the only safe painkiller for pregnant women, citing claims made by Trump and Kennedy.

canonical_title: Trump’s Pardons Aren’t Just Political; More Importantly, They’re Transactional

members.title: Trump’s Pardons Aren’t Just Political; More Importantly, They’re Transactional
key_points: President Donald Trump has issued more than 1,650 pardons and commutations involving individuals who played significant roles in matters directly related to him or his political agenda, representing over 84% of all pardons awarded during his tenure.

The pardons are not only political but transactional — Trump has used pardons as a tool to incentivize loyalty, particularly from those who engaged in illegal or legally dubious actions, such as helping to overturn the 2020 election or lying to investigators.

Individuals like Rudy Giuliani, Sidney Powell, Mark Meadows, and John Eastman explicitly expressed interest in receiving pardons, with Eastman stating he wanted to be on a 'pardon list' shortly after January 6, 2021.

digest_abridged:
President Trump has issued over 1,650 pardons, primarily targeting individuals involved in actions related to his political agenda, with explicit ties to post-2020 election efforts.

timeframes: after government reopening..up to one week

members.title: SNAP Benefits Still Delayed After Government Reopening Amid Conflicting Guidance
key_points: The federal government reopened on November 12, 2025, but the timing of full SNAP benefits for 42 million Americans remains uncertain across states.

The reopening measure signed by President Donald Trump includes a provision to restart the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), but does not resolve the timing of when benefits will be loaded onto EBT cards.
The USDA states that benefits could be available within 24 hours for most states after reopening, but it has not clarified whether this applies to states or to individual beneficiaries’ debit cards.

canonical_title: How France Remembers the November 2015 Terrorist Attacks in Paris
entities: Museum of terror attacks in France

members.title: How France Remembers the November 2015 Terrorist Attacks in Paris
key_points: The memory of the Nov. 13, 2015 Paris attacks remains strong in the public consciousness, with over 80% of people still recalling where they were when the attacks occurred.

Despite strong collective memory, there has been a significant decline in people’s ability to identify the three attack locations: outside the national soccer stadium, the Bataclan concert hall, and cafes/restaurants in central Paris, with 31% unable to name them in 2024.
The attacks were carried out by Islamic State extremists and involved coordinated shootings and suicide bombings, making them the deadliest and most complex Islamic State plot in Europe.

digest_abridged:
France commemorates the 2015 Paris attacks, where ISIS extremists carried out coordinated shootings and bombings.

canonical_title: Tracking States’ Unprecedented Redistricting Efforts

members.title: Tracking States’ Unprecedented Redistricting Efforts
key_points: President Donald Trump and Republicans are actively redrawing congressional maps to protect their narrow majority in the House ahead of the 2026 midterm elections.
Democrats are responding with their own redistricting efforts, leading to political battles across the country that will shape the midterm landscape.
In Utah, a judge rejected a Republican-drawn map from 2021 and ordered a new one that is likely to create a Democratic seat due to a violation of an anti-gerrymandering ballot measure.

members.title: Two of China’s most popular gay dating apps have disappeared from app stores
key_points: The disappearance of Blued and Finka from Chinese app stores reflects a broader pattern of increasing government suppression of LGBTQ+ content and activities in China.
China's online censorship regime, known as the Great Firewall, and ideological control over Western values have led to the removal of platforms promoting same-sex relationships.
Blued and Finka were accused of carrying 'vulgar content' or pornography, and their removal appears to be linked to compliance issues with Chinese internet regulations.

Qian fled China after authorities took notice and lived an extravagant lifestyle in Europe, including luxury hotels and high-end purchases.

canonical_title: What the US military is using to strike alleged drug boats

members.title: What the US military is using to strike alleged drug boats
key_points: The U.S. military has launched a campaign against alleged drug trafficking boats in the Pacific Ocean and Caribbean Sea using MQ-9 Reaper drones, AC-130J gunships, and fighter jets.

Since early September, 19 strikes have destroyed 20 boats and killed 76 people, with the campaign targeting vessels linked to drug cartels, primarily in the western Pacific route from Colombia to Mexico to the U.S.
The military has concentrated assets in Puerto Rico and El Salvador, including reactivation of Naval Station Roosevelt Roads and increased use of CSL Comalapa for surveillance and strikes.

members.title: Things are pretty crappy: 1 in 4 U.S. households living paycheck to paycheck
key_points: An estimated 24% of U.S. households are living paycheck to paycheck in 2025, spending over 95% of their income on necessities like housing, groceries, and utilities.
Lower-income households are seeing stagnant wage growth (1% year-over-year), falling behind inflation (3%) and significantly behind higher-income households (4% growth).
Millennials face an even wider wage gap: only 1% wage growth, compared to 6% for high-income workers.

canonical_title: Indigenous activists storm COP30 climate summit in Brazil, demanding action

members.title: Indigenous activists storm COP30 climate summit in Brazil, demanding action
key_points: Hundreds of Indigenous activists, including members of the Tupinamba community, protested at COP30 in Belem, Brazil, demanding climate justice and protection of their lands from agribusiness, oil exploration, and illegal logging.

Indigenous leaders, such as Gilmar and Leo Cerda, emphasized that climate action must include Indigenous peoples at the negotiation table, asserting that sustainability is rooted in traditional Indigenous knowledge and land stewardship.

The protest highlighted ongoing encroachment by industries like Petrobras on Amazonian territories, including a new offshore oil drilling license near the Amazon River mouth, which Indigenous groups see as contradictory to climate goals.

canonical_title: British Journalist Sami Hamdi Detained by U.S. ICE for Speaking Out on Gaza War

members.title: British Journalist Sami Hamdi Detained by U.S. ICE for Speaking Out on Gaza War
key_points: British journalist Sami Hamdi was detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for over two weeks after speaking at a pro-Palestinian event, despite claiming he was in the U.S. on a valid visa.

Hamdi alleges he was detained for speaking out against Israel’s war in Gaza, not for visa violations, and that he was subjected to harsh conditions, including being held in a small room with dozens of men and forced to wait over eight hours for medical care.
Hamdi was reportedly kept in shackles without being charged with a crime, which raises concerns about due process and the treatment of journalists during immigration detention.

members.title: U.S. bishops officially ban gender-affirming care at Catholic hospitals
key_points: U.S. Catholic bishops formally banned gender-affirming care for transgender patients at Catholic hospitals, reinforcing a long-standing conservative stance on medical interventions related to gender identity.
The ban builds on earlier Vatican and U.S. bishops' documents from 2023 and 2024, which outlined moral objections to procedures that alter a person's sex characteristics.
Catholic Health Association affirmed that transgender patients will still be treated with dignity and respect, emphasizing adherence to Catholic social teaching and care for marginalized populations.

canonical_title: How Trump-era funding cuts endanger efforts to empower Haiti’s farmers
entities: Center for Economic and Policy Research

members.title: How Trump-era funding cuts endanger efforts to empower Haiti’s farmers
key_points: The World Food Programme (WFP) is shifting from importing food to sourcing meals locally in Haiti, with over 32,000 farmers contributing to school meal programs that feed 600,000 students daily.
This transition supports local agriculture, farmer livelihoods, and children’s education by reducing hunger-related disruptions in learning.

Funding cuts under the Trump administration — including the suspension of USAID contracts and rescission of $4.9 billion in foreign aid — threaten these efforts, risking a reversal of progress toward local food procurement.

members.title: After 13 Years, Oklahoma Sex Offender Anthony Lennon Arrested Under Alias Justin Phillips
key_points: Anthony Lennon, a former Oklahoma sex offender, vanished in March 2012 after being charged with possession of child sexual abuse material and a $100,000 felony warrant was issued.
The crime scene at the Super 8 Motel showed suspicious evidence, including a name badge, blood patterns, and a TV left on, leading investigators to suspect Lennon may have staged his own abduction.
Over 13 years, law enforcement agencies, including Moore Police and the US Marshals Service, pursued the case through multiple investigations, search warrants, and cross-state leads.

canonical_title: U.S. Ends Penny Production After 230 Years in Major Monetary Shift

members.title: U.S. Ends Penny Production After 230 Years in Major Monetary Shift
key_points: The U.S. ended production of the penny in 2025 after more than 230 years, due to its production cost (nearly 4 cents) exceeding its face value (1 cent).
The final penny was pressed at the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia on November 12, 2025, with the last coins being auctioned off.
President Donald Trump had previously advocated for the penny's elimination, stating that it cost more to produce than its value.

canonical_title: Chess Federation Accuses Former Champion Kramnik of Harassing Rival Who Died

members.title: Chess Federation Accuses Former Champion Kramnik of Harassing Rival Who Died
key_points: The International Chess Federation (FIDE) filed a formal complaint against Vladimir Kramnik for allegedly harassing Daniel Naroditsky, a deceased American grandmaster, after making unproven cheating accusations.

Daniel Naroditsky, a prominent figure in the online chess community known for his educational YouTube content and livestreams, died at age 29, and his death was reportedly linked to emotional distress caused by Kramnik’s allegations.

Kramnik accused Naroditsky of cheating, despite Naroditsky denying the claims, and continued sharing such suspicions on social media, which critics say constituted harassment and a violation of dignity.

canonical_title: Sally Kirkland, Scene-Stealing Actress, Dies at 84

members.title: Sally Kirkland, Scene-Stealing Actress, Dies at 84
key_points: Sally Kirkland was a pioneering actress known for her sassy, unapologetic persona and bold performances in avant-garde theater and film.

She gained early recognition through Andy Warhol’s experimental film 'The 13 Most Beautiful Women' and the 1968 nude performance in 'Sweet Eros', which challenged norms around nudity and gender in performance art.
Her Oscar nomination for 'Anna' (1987) marked a major milestone in her career and highlighted her ability to portray complex, politically charged female characters with emotional depth and charisma.

canonical_title: Black box safety warning to be removed from hormone therapy for menopause

members.title: Black box safety warning to be removed from hormone therapy for menopause
key_points: The FDA is removing the black box warning on hormone therapy for menopause, which was first introduced in 2003 due to concerns from the Women’s Health Initiative study.
The black box warning previously stated that hormone therapy increases risks of breast cancer, stroke, blood clots, and dementia, leading to a 70% drop in prescriptions.
New evidence shows that starting hormone therapy before age 60 or within 10 years of menopause can reduce risks and improve outcomes, especially for symptom management.

canonical_title: Trump pens letter asking Israeli president to pardon Netanyahu in corruption trial

members.title: Trump Pens Letter Asking Israeli President to Pardon Netanyahu in Corruption Trial
key_points: US President Donald Trump sent a formal letter requesting Israeli President Isaac Herzog to pardon Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is facing charges of fraud, bribery, and breach of trust.

The letter, which Trump described as calling for a 'full pardon' of Netanyahu, frames the prosecution as a 'political, unjustified prosecution' and a 'witch hunt,' referencing past criticism of similar legal actions against him.

Netanyahu is the first incumbent Israeli prime minister to face criminal charges while in office; the trial began in May 2020 and includes multiple cases, with testimony having started in December 2024.

members.title: Adams Makes It Harder for Mamdani to Build Over Elizabeth Street Garden
key_points: Mayor Eric Adams initially supported replacing the Elizabeth Street Garden in Lower Manhattan with affordable housing, but reversed course in June 2024, opting instead to pursue housing elsewhere.

The city has now formally designated the Elizabeth Street Garden as permanent parkland through a letter from Louis Molina to Iris Rodriguez-Rosa, making it legally difficult to build housing on the site.
Zohran Mamdani, the incoming mayor, has publicly pledged to revive housing plans for the site, which has angered development advocates and raised concerns about political continuity and commitment.

key_points: Over 1,000 musicians and labels, including major artists like Lorde, Björk, and Massive Attack, are participating in a boycott called 'No Music for Genocide' to geo-block their music from Israel.
The boycott aims to isolate and delegitimize Israel in response to the UN-commissioned finding that Israel is committing genocide in Gaza.
The movement draws inspiration from historical cultural boycotts against apartheid South Africa, such as the Artists United Against Apartheid campaign involving Bruce Springsteen and Miles Davis.

canonical_title: Donald Trump Criticizes NFL's New Kickoff Format as 'Demeaning' and 'Unromantic'

members.title: Donald Trump Criticizes NFL's New Kickoff Format as 'Demeaning' and 'Unromantic'
key_points: President Donald Trump has been a vocal critic of the NFL’s new dynamic kickoff format since its debut, calling it 'terrible,' 'demeaning,' and 'unromantic,' and claiming it undermines the pageantry and spirit of football.

The new kickoff rule, introduced in 2024, requires players to line up with at least one foot on the receiving team’s 40-yard line and waits for the ball to touch the ground or be touched by a returner before moving, reducing collision speed and player contact.

The NFL argues that the new format is safer, with a 43% drop in concussions from 2021–2023 and a 57% increase in kickoff returns, including seven touchdown returns in 2024, indicating more excitement and fewer injuries.

This event provided a rare glimpse into the early universe, offering scientists insights into how supermassive black holes form and influence their surroundings.

key_points: Congress passed a short-term funding bill ending a 43-day federal shutdown, the longest in U.S. history, after a six-week stalemate over an Obamacare program.
The bill ensures continued funding for critical programs like SNAP and WIC, which serve millions of Americans and veterans, even in the event of future shutdowns.

The bipartisan vote included nearly all Republicans and several Democrats, with the final vote being 222 to 209, though Democrats criticized the bill for offering no guarantee of future health care subsidies.

canonical_title: 42 Million People Are Enrolled in SNAP. Who Are They?

members.title: 42 Million People Are Enrolled in SNAP. Who Are They?
key_points: SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) is the U.S. government's largest anti-hunger program, serving 42 million low-income Americans — one in eight — and helping them purchase groceries via EBT cards.

SNAP eligibility is based on income limits, typically 130% of the federal poverty level, with a household of two earning up to $529 per week ($27,495 annually) and a family of four up to $41,795 annually.
Nearly 90% of SNAP recipients are native-born U.S. citizens, and 96% are citizens, indicating strong ties to the American legal and social structure.

digest_abridged:
The U.S. SNAP program serves 42 million low-income Americans via EBT cards, with 90% being native-born citizens.

canonical_title: Italy probes claim that tourists paid to go to Bosnia to kill besieged civilians

members.title: Italy probes claim that tourists paid to go to Bosnia to kill besieged civilians
key_points: Italian prosecutors in Milan have opened an investigation into claims that Italian citizens and others paid to engage in sniper tourism during the Bosnian siege of Sarajevo in the early 1990s.

The allegations suggest that wealthy individuals, including Italians, were charged different rates to shoot at civilians — men, women, or children — with some paying up to €100,000 (equivalent to £88,000 today).

The claims are based on testimony from a Bosnian military intelligence officer who revealed that Bosnian colleagues discovered the 'safaris' in late 1993 and passed the information to Italy’s Sismi intelligence in early 1994.

canonical_title: Why home insurance is unaffordable, even in places without wildfires or hurricanes

members.title: Why home insurance is unaffordable, even in places without wildfires or hurricanes
key_points: Hailstorms, especially in the central U.S., are causing significant and increasing property damage, with Cozad, Nebraska, serving as a case example of a small town suffering extensive roof, siding, and window damage from a single storm.

The cost of home insurance is rising rapidly in the central U.S., with Nebraska having the highest average cost at $6,400 per year—nearly $4,000 above the national average—driven by climate-related increases in hail frequency and damage severity.
Insurance companies are passing on the costs of disaster recovery through higher premiums and increased deductibles, making policies less affordable and often covering only partial repair costs.

members.title: Negotiations Break Down 38-Day Government Shutdown After Moderate Democrats Agree to Bipartisan Deal with Republican Leader John Thune
key_points: A bipartisan deal to end the 38-day government shutdown was reached after moderate Democrats negotiated with Republican Majority Leader John Thune.
The deal included a moratorium on future federal workforce reductions (RIFs) through January, which was a key concession from the White House and a major factor in securing Democratic support.
Furloughed federal employees received back pay, but the original demand for extended Affordable Care Act (ACA) subsidies was not met, due to Republican resistance.

canonical_title: Could COVID-19 mRNA vaccines also fight cancer?
entities: European Society for Medical Oncology Congress
University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

members.title: Could COVID-19 mRNA vaccines also fight cancer?
key_points: mRNA COVID-19 vaccines may enhance the immune system's ability to detect and attack cancer cells, especially in 'cold' tumors that were previously resistant to immune detection.
Patients with advanced lung cancer who received an mRNA vaccine before immunotherapy showed a nearly doubling of median survival (from 20.6 to 37.3 months).
In metastatic melanoma patients, vaccinated individuals had a median survival of over three years, compared to less than two years in the unvaccinated group.

key_points: Jama'at Nusrat al-Islam wal-Muslimin (JNIM), an al-Qaeda-affiliated jihadist group, has launched a fuel blockade by attacking fuel tankers and kidnapping drivers, disrupting transport and economic activity in Mali.
The blockade has led to widespread shortages of fuel, causing schools and universities to close, food prices to triple, and hospitals to face power cuts due to diesel shortages.
Mali, being landlocked, relies on road transport from neighboring countries like Senegal and Ivory Coast, making fuel supply vulnerable to militant attacks along key highways.

The portrait was looted by Nazis during WWII and narrowly avoided destruction, surviving because it was not included in a Nazi exhibition due to its Jewish heritage.
The painting was once titled 'Portrait of Baroness Elisabeth Bachofen-Echt' but was corrected to reflect the woman's unmarried status at the time of painting, emphasizing historical accuracy.

- Added context of Nazi looting and survival due to Jewish heritage

key_points: The 30th United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP30) is being held in Belem, Brazil, bringing together over 50,000 attendees from 190+ countries to address the climate crisis.
The main focus of COP30 is not setting new goals but implementing past promises, such as phasing out fossil fuels and reducing deforestation, especially in the Amazon.
Brazil has proposed a Tropical Forests Forever Facility (TFFF) to raise $25 billion in pledges and attract an additional $100 billion from global markets for biodiversity and conservation.

canonical_title: The Last Penny Was Minted in Philadelphia: U.S. Ends Production After 238 Years

members.title: The Last Penny Was Minted in Philadelphia: U.S. Ends Production After 238 Years
key_points: The U.S. Mint stopped producing pennies in 2025, with the final coins minted in Philadelphia on November 12, 2025, under the direction of US Treasurer Brandon Beach.
The penny's production cost ($0.04) exceeds its face value ($0.01), leading to financial inefficiency and prompting its discontinuation.
Despite being legally tender, the penny's removal has caused significant logistical and financial problems for retailers, including rounding errors, lack of exact change, and legal exposure.

The U.S. ended penny minting in 2025 after 238 years, citing cost inefficiency.

canonical_title: France remembers Bataclan attacks but knows enemy has not gone away

members.title: France remembers Bataclan attacks but knows enemy has not gone away
key_points: The 2015 Bataclan attacks killed 130 people, including 90 in the concert hall, and remain a defining moment in modern French history.
Salah Abdeslam, the only jihadist survivor of the attacks, is serving a life sentence and has expressed openness to restorative justice, which has sparked debate among victims' families.
A former girlfriend of Abdeslam, Maëva B, a 27-year-old French convert to Islam, has been arrested on suspicion of plotting a violent jihadist attack.

canonical_title: U.S. Appeals Order to Use American Sign Language Interpreters at White House Briefings
entities: U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit

members.title: U.S. Appeals Order to Use American Sign Language Interpreters at White House Briefings
key_points: The White House is required under a federal court order to provide simultaneous American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation during press briefings when President Trump or press secretary Karoline Leavitt speaks.

The Department of Justice is appealing the order, arguing that ASL interpretation should only be provided during regularly scheduled press briefings and not during other events such as ceremonies or speeches where the president takes questions.

The White House currently has a vendor agreement that requires 24 hours' notice for ASL interpreters; in the event of an unforeseen absence of an interpreter, the White House will publish ASL interpretation as soon as practicable.

members.title: Gregory Bovino Planning to Leave Chicago Amid Legal Backlash and Public Criticism
key_points: Gregory Bovino, the top Border Patrol official under the Trump administration, is planning to leave Chicago as early as this week to continue immigration enforcement operations in other cities, including Charlotte, North Carolina, and New Orleans.

The decision follows a personal rebuke from US District Court Judge Sara Ellis, who found Bovino had lied about the use of tear gas and force against protesters during a hearing on November 6, and issued a preliminary injunction restricting the use of force against peaceful demonstrators.

The Trump administration has previously suggested New Orleans as a target for federal crackdowns, citing Governor Jeff Landry’s support and the perceived need to 'straighten out' a difficult area of the country.

members.title: Supreme Court Keeps Full SNAP Payments on Hold with Short-Term Order
key_points: The Supreme Court extended a short-term administrative stay that blocks the Trump administration from providing full SNAP benefits for November, maintaining a legal limbo that affects over 42 million Americans.
The extension is designed to delay enforcement of a lower court order requiring full SNAP payments, which would require a $4 billion transfer within federal funds.

canonical_title: James Vanderbilt's 'Nuremberg' explores the human horror in a Nazi leader's story

members.title: James Vanderbilt's 'Nuremberg' explores the human horror in a Nazi leader's story
key_points: The film 'Nuremberg' explores the psychological complexity of Nazi leadership through the relationship between psychiatrist Douglas Kelley and Hermann Göring.
The trial established foundational legal principles used in modern international criminal law, including the creation of the International Criminal Court.

The film highlights the paradox of human nature: how individuals like Göring, who loved family like ordinary people, still committed atrocities, making their actions more horrifying and universally relatable.

members.title: Supreme Court Extends Order Blocking Full SNAP Payments, with Shutdown Potentially Near an End
key_points: The Supreme Court extended a temporary order blocking full SNAP payments, delaying full benefit restoration until the government reopens.

canonical_title: Four potential obstacles in House vote to end US government shutdown

members.title: Four potential obstacles in House vote to end US government shutdown
key_points: The House of Representatives is set to vote on a spending bill to end a prolonged government shutdown, with the vote expected by Wednesday evening.
House Republicans do not need Democratic support to pass the bill, but the margin for error is extremely narrow—only two votes can be lost for the bill to pass.

A major point of contention is whether to renew health insurance tax credits for 24 million Americans; Senate Republicans agreed to a vote on extension, but House Speaker Mike Johnson has not committed to allowing such a vote.

canonical_title: Escaramuza: The Poetics of Home
entities: California, Idaho, Colorado, Oregon, Washington D.C.

members.title: Escaramuza: The Poetics of Home
key_points: Escaramuza is an all-female equestrian sport originating in Mexico and popularized in the U.S., challenging traditional gender norms in a historically male-dominated field.
The uniforms of escaramuza riders are highly regulated, requiring long, layered, lace-trimmed dresses, petticoats, bloomers, and uniform boots, reflecting strict cultural and gendered expectations.

Despite its vibrant visual appeal, the sport is rooted in patriarchal values, with women often facing marginalization, including being seen as 'second-class citizens' and facing internalized misogyny.

canonical_title: Is the US government shutdown over, and why did it happen?

members.title: Is the US government shutdown over, and why did it happen?
key_points: The US government shutdown, the longest in history, ended after 43 days, with federal employees facing unpaid work, flight cancellations, and disrupted services.
The 328-page funding bill passed both chambers with bipartisan support and was signed into law by President Donald Trump, restoring most federal operations.
Despite the resolution, some programs like Liheap and Head Start will take weeks to resume due to delays in staffing and administrative recovery.

members.title: Supreme Court Leans Against Rastafarian Man Seeking to Sue Prison Officials for Cutting His Dreadlocks
key_points: The Supreme Court appeared unconvinced that a Rastafarian man, Damon Landor, could sue prison officials for cutting his dreadlocks, despite his religious vow to keep his hair intact.
Landor’s case is grounded in the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA), a law designed to protect religious rights of incarcerated individuals.
Louisiana argues that RLUIPA is a spending contract between the federal government and states, meaning individual officials cannot be personally liable under it.

canonical_title: 2 Dead After Small Plane on Hurricane Relief Mission to Jamaica Crashes in Florida Neighborhood

members.title: 2 Dead After Small Plane on Hurricane Relief Mission to Jamaica Crashes in Florida Neighborhood
key_points: A small Beechcraft King Air turboprop plane, manufactured in 1976, crashed shortly after takeoff from Fort Lauderdale Executive Airport on November 11, 2025, killing Alexander Wurm, 53, and his daughter Serena, 22.

The plane was part of a hurricane relief mission to Jamaica following Hurricane Melissa, a Category 5 storm that devastated Jamaica, Cuba, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic, leaving over 90,000 families affected.

The crash occurred in a gated residential neighborhood in Coral Springs, Florida, narrowly missing homes and damaging property, including fence and palm trees, with fuel spillage affecting nearby homes.

canonical_title: Caste census: The case for and against counting castes in India

members.title: Caste census: The case for and against counting castes in India
key_points: Counting castes in India is not merely a data exercise—it is a political and social act with far-reaching implications for welfare policies, affirmative action, and the perception of inequality.

The 2027 census will be the first national census in nearly a century to record every caste, following pressure from opposition parties and at least three states that have already conducted their own caste surveys.
Advocates argue that a caste census will provide more accurate data to refine affirmative action policies, making welfare spending more targeted and equitable.

canonical_title: Hospitals knew a heart device led to more patients' deaths - but they kept using it
entities: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA)

members.title: Hospitals knew a heart device led to more patients' deaths - but they kept using it
key_points: Hospitals in the UK, including Harefield and Freeman, continued to use the Medtronic HeartWare HVAD device despite NHS data showing a 2.5x higher mortality rate compared to the Abbott Heartmate III.
Patients were not fully informed of long-term risks, and some were not advised of the financial relationships between clinicians and Medtronic.
A key device malfunction — failure to restart after being stopped — was identified in December 2020, after Greg Marshall's incident, and was not widely known earlier.

canonical_title: Will People Trust Voting by Phone? Alaska Is Going to Find Out

members.title: Will People Trust Voting by Phone? Alaska Is Going to Find Out
key_points: Anchorage, Alaska, will conduct the first large-scale trial of phone voting in the United States, allowing all voters to cast ballots via smartphone links during municipal elections in April 2025.
The initiative targets logistical challenges such as harsh weather, long distances, a transient population, and ballot delivery issues in rural areas.
Phone voting will apply only to local municipal races (city assembly and school board), not to state or federal offices.

key_points: The 'I've Had It' podcast, hosted by Jennifer Welch and Angie 'Pumps' Sullivan, has gained massive popularity among liberal voters who feel frustrated with both the Trump administration and the Democratic Party's lack of decisive action.

The podcast is known for its raw, unvarnished, and often impolite tone, using pejorative language and direct criticism of political figures, including Trump, Vice President Vance, and Democratic leaders like Hakeem Jeffries and Chuck Schumer.

A key point of contention is the criticism of Senator Cory Booker's response to whether Netanyahu is a war criminal, with Welch asserting that the answer is objectively 'yes' and accusing Booker of cowardice.

The genre faces a consistent pattern of weak openings and slow follow-through, even with strong source material or critical intent.

canonical_title: Rep. Adelita Grijalva Finally Sworn In, Paving Way for Epstein Files Vote

members.title: Rep. Adelita Grijalva Finally Sworn In, Paving Way for Epstein Files Vote
key_points: Rep. Adelita Grijalva was finally sworn in on November 12, 2025, after a 50-day delay that sparked controversy over procedural delays and political motivations.

The delay was attributed to Speaker Mike Johnson, who cited House custom and timing of the legislative session, but faced criticism from Democrats and constituents for obstructing her entry into Congress.

Grijalva’s swearing-in was a pivotal moment that enabled the House to vote on the release of Jeffrey Epstein case files, a highly contentious issue with implications for transparency and accountability in government.

The delay sparked outrage among Democrats and left constituents without representation, as Grijalva was unable to perform basic duties or open an office during the period.
Grijalva's swearing-in occurred immediately after the House reconvened to vote on a bill to reopen the government, emphasizing the timing's political significance.

canonical_title: Warren Buffett: ‘I’m going quiet’

members.title: Warren Buffett: ‘I’m going quiet’
key_points: Warren Buffett, the 95-year-old CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, will step down as CEO at the end of 2025, ending a 60-year leadership role that has defined the company's identity and investment philosophy.
Buffett will no longer write the annual shareholder letter but will continue to deliver a Thanksgiving message, maintaining a symbolic and public connection with shareholders.

He will increase the pace of philanthropy by transferring $1.35 billion in Berkshire Hathaway B-shares to four family foundations to ensure his estate is distributed before alternate trustees take over.

The NOAA has issued a G4 geomagnetic storm watch, indicating a severe storm that is stronger than initially predicted.
Astronomers and space agencies are observing auroras in the US, including states like Colorado, Chicago, Seattle, and Boston, due to solar particle interactions with Earth’s atmosphere.

entities: University of Hawaii’s Institute for Astronomy

members.title: Why are scientists rushing to study a comet from deep space?
key_points: 3I/ATLAS is the third interstellar object ever detected to pass through our solar system, following 1I/'Oumuamua and 2I/Borisov.
The comet has a teardrop-shaped coma and a solid icy nucleus estimated at no more than 5.6 km (3.5 miles) across, possibly as small as 440 meters.
It originated from another star system, formed in extremely cold environments, and contains carbon dioxide in its coma indicating a distant origin.

members.title: Judge Orders Release of Hundreds Arrested in Illinois Immigration Crackdown
key_points: A federal judge, Jeffrey Cummings, ordered the release of 615 individuals detained in Illinois as part of the Trump administration's 'Operation Midway Blitz' immigration crackdown, citing violations of a 2022 settlement agreement on warrantless arrests.
The National Immigrant Justice Center and ACLU argued that more than 3,000 people were unlawfully arrested between June and October 2025, with at least 1,100 having voluntarily left the country.
ICE agents conducted arrests in the Chicago area between June 11 and October 7, 2025, including the arrest of Diana Galeano, a teacher at Rayito de Sol day care, which sparked public outrage.

canonical_title: The U.S. Just Produced Its Last Penny After a More Than 200-Year Run

members.title: The U.S. Just Produced Its Last Penny After a More Than 200-Year Run
key_points: The U.S. Mint produced its last penny in 2025 after over 200 years of production, marking a significant shift in monetary policy.
Each penny costs nearly 4 cents to produce, making it a financial loss for the government, and the phase-out is expected to save about $56 million annually.
The vast majority of pennies in circulation do not circulate, sitting in jars or stored places, which contributes to the inefficiency of the penny.

canonical_title: Hannibal Gadhafi, Son of Late Libyan Leader, Released by Lebanon After 10 Years in Detention

members.title: Hannibal Gadhafi, Son of Late Libyan Leader, Released by Lebanon After 10 Years in Detention
key_points: Hannibal Gadhafi, son of former Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, was released from Lebanese detention after 10 years, following a bail reduction from $11 million to $900,000 and the lifting of a travel ban.

The release was facilitated by a Libyan delegation that paid the bail, marking a diplomatic effort between Libya and Lebanon to resolve a long-standing case involving alleged information withholding about the disappearance of Lebanese Shiite cleric Moussa al-Sadr.
The case has been a persistent political and cultural sore point in Lebanon, where the family of al-Sadr still holds hope that the cleric is alive, despite the widely held belief that he is deceased.

key_points: The Suneung exam is a high-stakes, nationwide event in South Korea that determines university admission and long-term life outcomes.
Blind students are given a 1.7 times longer exam duration (up to 13 hours) due to the complexity of braille materials and their need to process information through touch and sound.
Braille test papers are six to nine times thicker than standard versions due to the conversion of every sentence into raised dots, significantly increasing physical strain.

key_points: President Donald Trump pardoned Robert Harshbarger Jr., a licensed pharmacist who served four years in federal prison for substituting unapproved Chinese drugs for FDA-approved iron sucrose in 2013.
The substitution was part of a practice known as 'compounding,' where pharmacists provide unapproved drugs based on patient needs, and no patients were reported to have been harmed.
Prosecutors argued that the substitution posed a risk due to lack of FDA approval and safety assurance for imported drugs, though no direct harm occurred.

members.title: Government Reopens as Trump Signs Bill to End Nation’s Longest Shutdown
key_points: President Donald Trump signed a spending bill that ended a 43-day government shutdown, the longest in U.S. history.
The bill passed the House 222–209, with six Democrats joining Republicans, after eight Democratic senators broke ranks to allow the measure to advance.
The legislation funds the federal government through January 2026 and includes provisions to reverse layoffs and restore retroactive pay to furloughed workers.

canonical_title: Transgender TSA Officer Sues DHS Over Policy Banning Pat-Down Duties

members.title: Transgender TSA Officer Sues DHS Over Policy Banning Pat-Down Duties
key_points: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), through the Transportation Security Administration (TSA), implemented a policy in February 2025 that bans transgender officers from conducting pat-down screening duties or serving as witnesses in private screening areas, citing compliance with President Donald Trump’s 2021 executive order on gender categories.

This policy contradicts TSA’s prior 2021 directive that allowed officers to perform duties aligned with their gender identity, and has led to legal challenges, including a federal lawsuit filed by transgender officer Danielle Mittereder at Dulles International Airport.

The lawsuit alleges that the policy violates civil rights by restricting core job functions, limiting career advancement, and subjecting transgender officers to daily scrutiny and humiliation, despite no performance issues being previously reported.

canonical_title: The Shutdown Is Over. But for Federal Workers, the Anxiety Persists.
entities: United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America

members.title: The Shutdown Is Over. But for Federal Workers, the Anxiety Persists.
key_points: The 43-day government shutdown, the longest in U.S. history, caused significant personal and financial hardship for federal workers, including food insecurity, debt accumulation, and mental health strain.

Despite the shutdown ending, federal workers face ongoing uncertainty due to the lack of long-term funding, potential layoffs, and unresolved backlogs in services like veterans' benefits and social security processing.

President Trump's administration used the shutdown as a platform to push workforce reductions, threatening back pay and facing legal challenges, which deepened workers' distrust in government stability.

key_points: Democrats caved on extending enhanced Obamacare tax credits, accepting modest concessions in exchange for a Senate vote on the subsidies and an agreement to reverse President Trump’s efforts to lay off federal workers.

key_points: The series 'The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives' returns for its third season with heightened drama, focusing on personal relationships, emotional conflicts, and revelations about infidelity and open marriage practices among Mormon women.

Paul formed 'MomTok', a community of Mormon mothers on TikTok, which has grown into a platform with millions of followers and lucrative sponsorship opportunities.

canonical_title: Google launches a lawsuit targeting text message scammers
entities: Scam Compound Accountability and Mobilization (SCAM) Act

members.title: Google launches a lawsuit targeting text message scammers
key_points: Google has filed a lawsuit against a Chinese-based criminal organization called 'Lighthouse' that operates a 'Phishing-as-a-Service' business, offering fake website templates to scammers.
The Lighthouse network created thousands of phishing websites that mimic legitimate U.S. institutions such as the U.S. Postal Service, New York City government, West Virginia DMV, and others.
Over 100 of the phishing templates include Google's logo in places where users are prompted to sign in or pay, creating a false sense of legitimacy and undermining user trust.

members.title: White House Weighs Stepped Up Domestic Travel and Speeches to Improve Trump’s Standing on the Economy
key_points: President Donald Trump is considering increased domestic travel and economy-focused speeches to improve public perception of his economic performance, especially amid growing public anxiety about affordability.

Americans' perception of economic hardship is strong, with 61% of a CNN poll saying Trump’s policies have worsened economic conditions — higher than Biden’s 58% — indicating a significant gap between policy claims and public sentiment.

Trump's advisers have urged him to stop dismissing economic anxiety, emphasizing that people’s lived experiences are real and that policy actions like deregulation and tax cuts need time to show results.

canonical_title: Longest Government Shutdown in History Ends Amid Public Outcry and Political Fallout

members.title: Longest Government Shutdown in History Ends Amid Public Outcry and Political Fallout
key_points: The longest government shutdown in U.S. history ended on November 12, 2025, after a six-week period of no new federal funding.

Democrats demanded an extension of the Affordable Care Act’s enhanced tax credit, which would have prevented a significant spike in health insurance premiums and the loss of coverage for over 2 million Americans.

Republicans, who control Congress, refused to negotiate on the tax credit extension and instead passed a short-term funding bill with bipartisan support, citing partisan demands as the reason for the standoff.

digest_abridged:
A six-week government shutdown ended on November 12, 2025, after Democrats pushed for an Affordable Care Act tax credit extension, which Republicans declined to support.

- Shutdown extended to six weeks, longest in U.S. history
- Democrats secured tax credit extension as key demand
- Republicans rejected negotiations, citing partisan demands

canonical_title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16

members.title: Australia adds Reddit, Kick to social media ban for children under 16
key_points: Australia is implementing a ban on children under 16 accessing social media platforms including Reddit, Kick, Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Threads, TikTok, X, and YouTube, effective December 10, 2025.
The ban is driven by concerns over harmful algorithms, addictive design features, and the impact of online platforms on children’s mental health and development.

The eSafety Commissioner, Julie Inman Grant, emphasized that the policy aims to protect children and give parents peace of mind, while also evaluating unintended consequences such as changes in sleep patterns, physical activity, and social interaction.

members.title: What’s in the bill to reopen the federal government?
key_points: The bill provides temporary funding for most federal agencies through January 30, 2026, ending the longest federal shutdown in U.S. history.
The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) is fully funded through September 30, including replenishment of its contingency fund and support for school meals.
The WIC program receives $8.2 billion — a $603 million increase — and its contingency fund is restored.

canonical_title: At Least 12 Killed in Islamabad Suicide Attack – the Most Deadly Assault in the Pakistani Capital Since 2008

members.title: At Least 12 Killed in Islamabad Suicide Attack – the Most Deadly Assault in the Pakistani Capital Since 2008
key_points: A suicide bombing in Islamabad killed 12 people and injured over 20, marking the deadliest such attack in the city in nearly two decades.
Jamaat-ul-Ahrar (JuA), a militant faction of the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), claimed responsibility for the attack, although the TTP distanced itself from the incident.
The attack occurred in the parking lot of the judicial complex near the High Court, where a man was observed loitering and attempted to enter before detonating a device on a police car.

members.title: California plans to revoke 17,000 commercial driver's licenses given to immigrants
key_points: California plans to revoke 17,000 commercial driver's licenses issued to immigrants due to expiration dates being past the legal status end dates.
The revocation follows criticism from Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy, who claims California violated federal standards by issuing licenses to undocumented individuals.
California's governor, Gavin Newsom, maintains that all revoked licenses had valid federal work authorizations, though the state law requires license expiration to align with legal status end dates.

members.title: At least 27 inmates killed by ‘asphyxiation’ in southern Ecuador in wave of prison violence
key_points: At least 31 inmates died in a series of violent clashes between rival gangs, Los Lobos and Sao-Box, in the Machala Detention Center in southern Ecuador on November 10, 2025.
Twenty-seven of the dead were killed by asphyxiation inside shared cells during a retaliatory attack by Los Lobos following an initial assault by Sao-Box.
Interior Minister John Reimberg reported that the first attack occurred in the early morning and resulted in four inmate deaths and 36 wounded, with two officers injured.

canonical_title: Immigrants with obesity, diabetes and other health problems may be denied visas

members.title: Immigrants with obesity, diabetes and other health problems may be denied visas
key_points: The Trump administration has issued new visa guidelines requiring visa officers to assess applicants' health status, particularly for chronic conditions like diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular diseases, respiratory diseases, cancers, metabolic and mental health disorders, and neurological conditions.
The guidance defines applicants with such conditions as potentially becoming a 'public charge' due to projected long-term medical costs, leading to possible visa denials.
Visa officers are instructed to evaluate whether applicants can afford medical care without relying on public assistance or long-term government institutions.

members.title: Seven migrants rescued after Mediterranean shipwreck leaves 42 presumed dead
key_points: A total of 42 migrants are presumed dead after a dinghy capsized in the Mediterranean near Zuwara, Libya, on 3 November 2025.
The vessel carried 49 people (47 men and 2 women), and only seven survived after being stranded at sea for six days.
The survivors are from Sudan, Nigeria, Cameroon, and Somalia, with 29 from Sudan, eight from Somalia, three from Cameroon, and two from Nigeria.

canonical_title: FDA Removes Black Box Warning on Hormone Therapy for Menopause, Sparking Debate Over Evidence and Balance

members.title: FDA Removes Black Box Warning on Hormone Therapy for Menopause, Sparking Debate Over Evidence and Balance
key_points: The FDA, under Commissioner Dr. Marty Makary, is removing the black box warning on estrogen-containing hormone therapies for menopause, citing updated scientific evidence and calling it a correction to a historical medical misstep.

This decision is significant because it may restore access to hormone therapy for millions of women, potentially reducing menopausal symptoms and offering long-term benefits in heart disease and dementia prevention.

However, experts like Dr. Leslie Cho and Dr. Rebecca Thurston argue that the evidence is not robust enough to justify removing the warning from systemic therapies (e.g., pills, injections), which are linked to increased risks of blood clots and cancer.

digest_abridged:
The FDA removes a black box warning on estrogen hormone therapy for menopause, citing updated evidence, sparking debate over safety in systemic treatments.

- FDA removes black box warning on estrogen therapy for menopause citing updated evidence
- Critics argue evidence for safety in systemic therapies remains insufficient

canonical_title: Kazakhstan follows Russia in banning ‘LGBTQ propaganda’

members.title: Kazakhstan follows Russia in banning ‘LGBTQ propaganda’
key_points: Kazakhstan’s lower parliament, the Mäjilis, has advanced a new anti-LGBTQ legislation that mirrors Russia’s 2022 'propaganda' ban, prohibiting dissemination of information on non-traditional sexual orientation or pedophilia in public, media, and online spaces.

The proposed law claims to 'protect children from harmful content' but is criticized by human rights organizations as violating international human rights standards and promoting stigma, discrimination, and censorship.

The legislation must still be approved by the Senate, and it is seen by LGBTQ rights defenders and international groups as a sign of political alignment with Russia, undermining Kazakhstan’s sovereignty and constitutional principles.

Kazakhstan's legislature advances a law banning LGBTQ+ content in public and media spaces, mirroring Russia’s 2022 ban.

What changed:
- New legislation introduced in Mäjilis mirrors Russia’s 2022 anti-propaganda law
- Law now requires Senate approval, pending final legislative passage

canonical_title: FDA and HHS Remove Black Box Warnings on Hormone Therapy for Menopause, Sparking Debate Over Evidence and Safety

members.title: FDA and HHS Remove Black Box Warnings on Hormone Therapy for Menopause, Sparking Debate Over Evidence and Safety
key_points: The FDA, under Commissioner Dr. Marty Makary, and HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced the removal of most black box warnings on hormone therapy for menopause, reversing a 2003 policy decision.

The decision is based on a review of recent scientific evidence and an expert panel discussion, though experts note that the evidence reviewed is not as comprehensive or balanced as typical FDA processes.

Hormone therapy, especially systemic forms like oral pills and transdermal patches, is not risk-free; critics point out that the benefits are overstated and that risks—especially for heart disease, blood clots, and breast cancer—remain significant.

The FDA and HHS removed black box warnings on hormone therapy for menopause, citing updated evidence, amid criticism over risk balance.

canonical_title: Women face a much higher risk of homicide, especially from guns, during pregnancy
entities: Cry Loud, Spare Not, Speak Up

members.title: Women face a much higher risk of homicide, especially from guns, during pregnancy
key_points: Pregnant women in the United States face a significantly higher risk of homicide, especially from firearms, with more than two-thirds of pregnancy-associated homicides involving guns.

A study published in JAMA Network Open found that every 1% increase in state-level firearm ownership is associated with a 6% increase in all-cause homicide and an 8% increase in firearm-specific homicide rates among pregnant women.
The highest rates of homicide in pregnant women occur among those aged 20 to 24, compared to 25 to 29 years old for non-pregnant women.

canonical_title: The U.S. saw vivid northern lights as far south as Florida — and more could be coming

members.title: The U.S. saw vivid northern lights as far south as Florida — and more could be coming
key_points: The northern lights were visible across a broad U.S. region, including Idaho, Iowa, Missouri, New Mexico, New York, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, and Washington, with sightings as far south as Florida and Alabama — a rare occurrence due to the intensity of the geomagnetic storm.

The auroras were caused by two coronal mass ejections (CMEs) from the Sun, with a third and potentially stronger CME expected to arrive midday Wednesday, increasing the risk of severe space weather events.
The geomagnetic storm reached G4 level on NOAA’s five-step scale, indicating a major disturbance that can disrupt satellites, GPS systems, radio communications, and power grids.

Szalay's work is notable for its sparse writing and deliberate omission of key life events (such as incarceration and wartime service in Iraq), which critics found both daring and thought-provoking.

canonical_title: Russia loses legal battle to build embassy near Australia’s Parliament

members.title: Russia loses legal battle to build embassy near Australia’s Parliament
key_points: Australia’s High Court ruled in 2025 that the government’s decision to cancel the Russian embassy lease was a lawful exercise of legislative power under the Constitution.
The site, located about 300 meters from Parliament House, was deemed a security risk by Australian intelligence agencies (ASIO), prompting the government to revoke the lease in 2023.
Russia challenged the revocation, claiming it violated constitutional principles, but the court upheld Australia’s authority to act in the interest of national security.

members.title: Carbon Dioxide Emissions Head for Another Record in 2025
key_points: Global CO₂ emissions are projected to reach a record high in 2025, increasing by 1.1% from 2024.
China's emissions appear to be flattening after decades of growth, with a projected increase of only 0.4% and potential decline, due to massive investments in wind, solar, and electric vehicles.
U.S. emissions are expected to rise by 1.9% due to cold weather, increased heating demand, and higher coal use during energy export shifts.

digest_abridged:
Global CO₂ emissions reach a record high in 2025, driven by U.S. heating demand and coal use, while China's emissions plateau due to renewable investments.

The incident involved a woman being racially abused and assaulted by a man and woman who were walking in front of her family, including a child in a pushchair, and who then used illegal pepper spray.
The use of pepper spray in the UK is illegal, which adds legal and moral weight to the incident.

canonical_title: Michelle Obama’s New Book Is a Historical Document Dressed Up as a Coffee-Table Tome

members.title: Michelle Obama’s New Book Is a Historical Document Dressed Up as a Coffee-Table Tome
key_points: Michelle Obama’s book 'The Look' is a historical document that reveals how fashion evolved into a deliberate instrument of soft diplomacy and political communication during her time as first lady.

The book highlights the establishment of a formal stylist position — Meredith Koop — as the first first lady to have such a role, marking a shift from traditional, one-designer pageantry to a dynamic, strategic approach to visual representation.

Mrs. Obama’s choices were intentionally made to promote diversity in fashion, especially by choosing designers from underrepresented backgrounds or international alliances to reflect global inclusivity and cultural respect.

Michelle Obama's book 'The Look' documents fashion as a strategic tool of soft diplomacy during her first lady tenure.

canonical_title: U.S. Bishops Elect New Leader as Concerns Mount Over Treatment of Migrants

members.title: U.S. Bishops Elect New Leader as Concerns Mount Over Treatment of Migrants
key_points: The U.S. Roman Catholic bishops elected Archbishop Paul S. Coakley of Oklahoma City as president and Bishop Daniel E. Flores of Brownsville, Texas, as vice president during their annual meeting in Baltimore.
The election reflects deep concern over the treatment of migrants, particularly in the context of the Trump administration’s aggressive deportation policies.
Archbishop Coakley, described as an institutionalist with ties to the church’s right wing, emphasized that Jesus was once a refugee and called on Catholics to support immigrant families.

canonical_title: A seismic shift in computing is on the horizon (and it’s not AI)
entities: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

members.title: A seismic shift in computing is on the horizon (and it’s not AI)
key_points: Quantum computing represents a fundamental shift in computing, not just a faster version of classical computers, relying on quantum principles like superposition and entanglement.
Qubits can exist in multiple states simultaneously (like a spinning coin), enabling vastly faster computation for complex problems in chemistry, cryptography, and finance.

Major tech companies — IBM, Google, Microsoft — are actively developing quantum processors with new chips such as Loon, Nighthawk, Majorana 1, and Willow, each with improvements in stability and computational power.

members.title: Tatsuya Nakadai, an icon of Japanese cinema, has died at 92
key_points: Tatsuya Nakadai, a legendary Japanese actor, died at 92, marking the end of an era in Japanese cinema.
He was central to the 'Golden Age' of Japanese film, working with iconic directors such as Akira Kurosawa and Masaki Kobayashi.
Nakadai’s stage background and commitment to theater acting influenced his distinctive performance style, especially in films like Harakiri.

canonical_title: South Korea’s former PM, spy chief arrested over martial law declaration

members.title: South Korea’s former PM, spy chief arrested over martial law declaration
key_points: Former South Korean Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn was arrested for inciting an insurrection by calling for the arrest of the National Assembly speaker and the eradication of individuals accused of electoral fraud.

Former head of the National Intelligence Service (NIS), Cho Tae-yong, was arrested for failing to report plans for martial law to the National Assembly despite knowing the actions were illegal, violating the NIS Act.

Former President Yoon Suk-yeol, removed from office in April 2024, is now detained and facing charges of attempting to provoke a military conflict with North Korea through covert drone operations and abusing power.

canonical_title: How can food be political? Families in state that pioneered SNAP speak of hardship

members.title: How can food be political? Families in state that pioneered SNAP speak of hardship
key_points: SNAP benefits are essential for millions of Americans, especially low-income families in rural and economically disadvantaged areas.
The U.S. government shutdown in late 2025 led to disruptions in SNAP funding, forcing families to make difficult choices about food, rent, utilities, and healthcare.
West Virginia, the first state to pilot the SNAP program in 1961, now faces increased food insecurity due to both reduced benefits and a surge in demand from furloughed federal workers.

canonical_title: A Kansas County Agrees to Pay $3 Million and Apologize for Raid on Small-Town Newspaper

members.title: A Kansas County Agrees to Pay $3 Million and Apologize for Raid on Small-Town Newspaper
key_points: A Kansas county, Marion County, agreed to pay $3 million and apologize for a 2023 raid on the Marion County Record, a small-town newspaper.
The raid involved the search of the newspaper's office and the home of its publisher and a councilwoman, including seizure of reporters' personal devices.
Marion Police Department Chief Gideon Cody suggested the raid was based on a belief that a reporter unlawfully obtained a restaurant owner’s driving records, though this claim was later challenged.

members.title: A Kansas County Agrees to Pay $3 Million and Apologize for a Raid on a Small-Town Newspaper
key_points: Marion County agreed to pay $3 million and apologize for a 2023 raid on the Marion County Record, a small-town newspaper.
The raid involved the search of the newspaper’s offices and the homes of its publisher and a councilwoman, with seizure of reporters’ cell phones and computers.

Marion Police Department Chief Gideon Cody claimed the raid was based on allegations that a reporter unlawfully obtained a restaurant owner’s driving records; he later resigned and was charged with interfering with the judicial process.

canonical_title: Turkish prosecutor seeks 2,000 years for jailed opposition mayor of Istanbul

members.title: Turkish prosecutor seeks 2,000 years for jailed opposition mayor of Istanbul
key_points: Turkish prosecutor Akin Gurlek has demanded a sentence of over 2,000 years for Ekrem Imamoglu, the opposition mayor of Istanbul, in a corruption indictment involving 402 suspects.
The indictment claims Imamoglu led a criminal organization that caused 160 billion lira ($3.8 billion) in state losses over a 10-year period through bribery, fraud, and bid-rigging.

The indictment includes an organization chart placing Imamoglu as the founder and head of the alleged criminal network and cites digital, video, and expert analysis from the Financial Crimes Investigation Board (MASAK).

canonical_title: As Shutdown Nears End, Trump Still Confronts Soaring Health Costs

members.title: As Shutdown Nears End, Trump Still Confronts Soaring Health Costs
key_points: The U.S. government shutdown, one of the longest in history, is ending due to a compromise by a splinter group of Democrats who dropped their demand to extend health insurance subsidies, shifting focus to health care affordability.
President Donald Trump has not proposed a viable alternative to Obamacare, offering only vague plans such as direct cash payments to patients instead of insurance companies.

Trump's proposal to shift subsidy funds to individuals in flexible accounts is similar to a plan by Senator Bill Cassidy, but lacks strong evidence of cost savings and is estimated to cost around $350 billion over ten years.

canonical_title: After festival of lights, New Delhi plunged into toxic darkness and world’s most polluted air
timeframes: After Diwali celebrations, early morning of November 11, 2025..2:50 AM EST, Tue November 11, 2025

members.title: After festival of lights, New Delhi plunged into toxic darkness and world’s most polluted air
key_points: New Delhi’s PM2.5 pollution levels exceeded 40 times the World Health Organization’s annual guideline, making it one of the world’s most polluted cities.
The pollution worsened after Diwali fireworks, despite a 2020 ban on traditional firecrackers and a Supreme Court-allowed limited use of 'green' firecrackers.
Poor enforcement of the green firecracker curfew allowed non-green firecrackers to be used, contributing to high pollution levels.
