canonical_title: Former Aide to California Governor Indicted for Alleged Theft of Campaign Funds from Ex-Health Secretary
entities: FBI Sacramento Special Agent in Charge Sid Patel

members.title: Former Aide to California Governor Indicted for Alleged Theft of Campaign Funds from Ex-Health Secretary
key_points: Dana Williamson, a former top aide to California Governor Gavin Newsom, has been indicted on federal charges for allegedly stealing campaign funds from former Health Secretary Xavier Becerra.

The scheme involved funneling over $225,000 from Becerra’s dormant campaign account to Sean McCluskie, who was Becerra’s chief of staff at the time, through a web of fake business contracts and false billing.
Williamson used her political consulting firm to bill campaign funds for services that were never rendered, with the money being redirected to her and McCluskie’s wife.

canonical_title: The last-ever penny was minted today in Philadelphia

members.title: The last-ever penny was minted today in Philadelphia
key_points: The last U.S. penny was minted in Philadelphia on November 12, 2025, ending 238 years of production.
The penny costs nearly four cents to produce, more than its face value, making it economically unsustainable.
Despite being legally tender, the penny's removal from circulation has caused widespread retail and consumer problems, including rounding to the nearest nickel.

members.title: Speaker Johnson’s narrow majority shrinks further after Democrat Adelita Grijalva sworn in
key_points: House Speaker Mike Johnson's majority has been reduced to 219 Republicans and 214 Democrats after Democrat Adelita Grijalva's swearing-in, making the chamber even more divided.
The narrowest House majority since the 1930s has created significant challenges for Republican legislative efforts, leaving little room for error in passing major bills.
Grijalva's entry into Congress is pivotal as she is expected to deliver the decisive vote on a petition to force a House vote on the release of Jeffrey Epstein case files.

canonical_title: He Died at a School for Disabled People. Decades Later, His Brother Sought Answers.

members.title: He Died at a School for Disabled People. Decades Later, His Brother Sought Answers.
key_points: John Scott was born in 1955 with severe spina bifida and died at 17 in 1973 at the Fernald School, where he was buried in an unmarked grave.
The Fernald School, like many mid-20th century institutions for people with developmental disabilities, was plagued by abuse, poor conditions, and lack of medical care.
David Scott, John’s younger brother, spent decades in silence and trauma before beginning a search in 2021, motivated by the birth of his son Michael with cerebral palsy.

key_points: Federal tax credits for electric vehicles were eliminated by Congress and President Trump, which directly reduced demand for high-priced EVs like the F-150 Lightning and Porsche Taycan.
Consumers are shifting from luxury EVs (over $80,000) to more affordable models such as the Chevrolet Equinox and Hyundai Ioniq 5, which start at around $35,000.

Ford halted production of the F-150 Lightning due to declining demand, rising costs, and a supplier fire affecting aluminum supply; the company plans to reintroduce a smaller, lower-cost Lightning pickup in 2027 at around $30,000.

John Hoffman and his wife Yvette.

The case involves claims by Boelter that he was conducting an undercover investigation into alleged cover-ups of 400 COVID-19 vaccine-related deaths, which he said went awry when the Hoffmans tried to push him out the door.

Boelter, a 58-year-old politically conservative evangelical Christian and former preacher, pleaded not guilty to murder and attempted murder charges, with no clear explanation for the attack on the Hortmans and their dog, Gilbert.

canonical_title: A ‘cannibal storm’ from the sun triggered auroras. Another round is on its way
entities: National Weather Service’s Space Weather Prediction Center

members.title: A ‘cannibal storm’ from the sun triggered auroras. Another round is on its way
key_points: A 'cannibal storm' from the sun, where a second coronal mass ejection (CME) caught up and merged with a first, causing intensified geomagnetic activity, was responsible for spectacular auroras visible in southern US states like Florida and Alabama.
The event has been classified as G3 by the Space Weather Prediction Center, with a potential rise to G4 on Thursday and possible G5 (extreme) levels, as predicted by the British Geological Survey.
This solar storm is linked to active region AR 14274 on the sun, which produced three X-class solar flares and multiple CMEs, with the most intense one occurring on Tuesday.

canonical_title: Millions saw unexpected northern lights, as a wild solar storm unfolded across the world
entities: National Weather Service’s Space Weather Prediction Center

members.title: Millions saw unexpected northern lights, as a wild solar storm unfolded across the world
key_points: A severe geomagnetic storm caused dazzling auroras to be visible in unexpected locations, including in the US as far south as Florida and across the UK, due to dual solar storms from the sun.
The storm was caused by two Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) from the sun’s active region AR 14274, with the second CME catching up to and combining with the first, creating a 'cannibal storm'.
This event led to a large solar particle storm and the largest measured geoelectric field since 2012, reaching 3.5 volts per kilometer in the Shetland Islands.

canonical_title: Key Netanyahu Minister Steps Down From Israel’s Government

members.title: Key Netanyahu Minister Steps Down From Israel’s Government
key_points: Ron Dermer, Israel’s minister of strategic affairs, has resigned from the government, citing a commitment to serve through a 'critical' period in Israel’s history.

Dermer, a long-time confidant of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, was instrumental in shaping Israel’s war strategy, including cease-fire negotiations with Hamas and securing U.S. support for airstrikes on Iran’s nuclear facilities.
Dermer’s resignation comes one month after the return of all remaining hostages from Gaza and the handover of most deceased captives’ remains, signaling a potential shift in the war’s trajectory.

members.title: Venezuela announces ‘massive mobilization’ of military forces as America’s largest warship sails into region
key_points: Venezuela has announced a 'massive mobilization' of military forces, including land, air, naval, and reserve units, in response to a US naval build-up in the Caribbean Sea.

The mobilization involves the Bolivarian Militia, a civilian reserve force established by Hugo Chávez, and is described by Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino López as a defense against an 'imperialist threat'.

The US Navy's largest warship, the USS Gerald R. Ford, arrived in the US Southern Command area of operations, including Latin America, with a strike group of nine air squadrons, two Arleigh Burke-class destroyers, and over 4,000 sailors.

canonical_title: How will ‘limited’ US nuclear tests avoid any explosions?

members.title: How will ‘limited’ US nuclear tests avoid any explosions?
key_points: The U.S. is planning noncritical, non-explosive nuclear tests involving components of nuclear weapons, not full nuclear detonations.
These tests are designed to ensure the safety, reliability, and functionality of new nuclear weapon systems without violating the 1992 nuclear test moratorium.

The U.S. government, including Energy Secretary Chris Wright and National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA), asserts that advanced simulations and subcritical experiments are sufficient to maintain nuclear stockpile integrity.

canonical_title: At least 27 people sickened and 6 dead in latest US listeria outbreak. What you should know
entities: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

members.title: At least 27 people sickened and 6 dead in latest US listeria outbreak. What you should know
key_points: Six people have died and at least 27 people have been sickened in a multistate listeria outbreak linked to recalled prepared pasta meals.
The outbreak is linked to products sold at major grocery chains including Albertsons, Kroger, Sprouts Farmers Market, and Trader Joe’s.

Listeria monocytogenes is a dangerous bacterium that can grow at refrigerator temperatures and is commonly found in ready-to-eat foods such as deli meats, soft cheeses, smoked fish, and refrigerated meals.

canonical_title: UK sentences Chinese scammer after record-breaking Bitcoin seizure

members.title: UK sentences Chinese scammer after record-breaking Bitcoin seizure
key_points: Zhimin Qian, a 47-year-old Chinese woman also known as Yadi Zhang, was sentenced to 11 years and 8 months in prison for masterminding a years-long investment scam in China (2014–2017) that defrauded 128,000 people of £4.6bn.
UK authorities seized a record-breaking 61,000 Bitcoin in the investigation, making it the largest cryptocurrency seizure in UK history and the largest money laundering case by value.
Qian fled China in 2017 and spent seven years on the run, traveling between the UK and other countries due to the absence of extradition agreements with China.

canonical_title: Federal Judge Plans to Release Some Immigrants Arrested in Chicago Area

members.title: Federal Judge Plans to Release Some Immigrants Arrested in Chicago Area
key_points: Judge Jeffrey Cummings, a federal judge nominated by President Joe Biden, has ruled that 615 immigrants arrested during Operation Midway Blitz in Chicago must be released, with conditions including posting bond and electronic monitoring.
The ruling stems from a 2018 consent decree that prohibited warrantless arrests by immigration agents in Illinois and six other states, which was violated during the Trump administration’s crackdown.

The judge found that many of the recent arrests were made without warrants, violating the consent decree, and ordered the government to disclose information about additional arrests beyond the 615 detainees.

canonical_title: House votes to fund government, ending longest ever government shutdown

members.title: House votes to fund government, ending longest ever government shutdown
key_points: The government shutdown was the longest in history, lasting 43 days and affecting millions of Americans, including cutting pay for federal workers and disrupting critical services like air traffic control.
The bill passed by the House, despite a narrow Republican majority, with 222 votes in favor and 209 opposed, including six Democrats joining Republicans.
The bill does not address the core issue of expiring Affordable Care Act subsidies, which Democrats had demanded during the shutdown.

canonical_title: By Not Funding Food Stamps, Trump Risks Lasting Damage to Safety Net

members.title: By Not Funding Food Stamps, Trump Risks Lasting Damage to Safety Net
key_points: The federal government's 43-day shutdown caused a significant interruption to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), affecting approximately 42 million low-income Americans.
President Donald Trump refused to fund SNAP benefits during the shutdown, citing political leverage and opposition to expanding social programs, despite ample leftover funds being available.

Trump’s administration resisted disbursing full food stamp benefits, leading to legal challenges, including two trips to the Supreme Court, and in at least one state, threatened to shut off SNAP cards used by families.

During a 43-day federal shutdown, President Trump withheld SNAP funding, disrupting food assistance for 42 million low-income Americans.

canonical_title: What’s Behind the Coming House Vote on Releasing the Epstein Files

members.title: What’s Behind the Coming House Vote on Releasing the Epstein Files
key_points: A bipartisan discharge petition, signed by 218 representatives, succeeded in forcing the House to vote on a bill requiring the Justice Department to release Epstein files within 30 days.
The petition bypassed House leadership control by circumventing committee referrals, a key procedural mechanism used to challenge the status quo.
Despite President Trump and Republican leaders opposing the bill, the measure advanced due to sustained bipartisan pressure from constituents and elected officials.
